instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which looks like some previous liquid damage but the machine boots. Re-Installed MacOS which took more time than normal, it seems that the machine is very slow.  Held down 'D' to run diag on boot but MacOS reports no issues found: Code App0000.

      Also, when turning on the machine it's necessary to hold down the power button until the chime completes to get the boot going.

      Eventually installed 'istat menus' and the it's showing the 'Kernel Task' @ 244%.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Disconnect internal SSD and try USB macOS.
If still the same, try clean ME BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: Can you tell me where to get a clean ME BIOS for a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Several threads have links posted.

Just in case,
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/10PQbSQ8wrvXxrLrXypNT0Mtwnzq5coXt/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Connected the Medusa, read the BIOS...tried to clean the ME and got an error starting the write ROM.  So I loaded the file provided into Medusa and tried to write the ROM but got an 'Erase Error: 8ver' '00% W:001000'

Any suggestion as to how to get around this?
Thx

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Do not connect charger, nor battery to MLB.
Just inject external 3V into <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
I use a wire soldered to Medusa, to get this voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: curious as to where on the Medusa you grab the 3v from?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Port A connector; the one who goes to Mac board.
Second pin has 3V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: I had an issue with the A4160 EasyFlash (connector came off the board), so I tried the A4140 EasyFlash and was able to write the ROM but I'm not getting a the Apple logo to boot up anymore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: Did you verify Medusa ROM against Mac ROM?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: Yes I did verify the Medusa ROM against Mac ROM

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message: Put back the backup BIOS and see what happens...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Placed the backup BIOS back and the laptop booted up at normal speed initially.... ran the browser and youtube video and then the machine started to slow down and the kernel task when backup to very high again.

Is it possible some sensor causing this issue?

After having the machine on for about 10-15 minutes running iStat Menus....the machine suddenly turned off as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
The posted BIOS should be good.
You didn't write it correctly, maybe; try it again.
What about MLB temps, especially CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
I'll re-try the posted BIOS, not sure what might have happened.
MLB temps, posted around 43....
Will update once I get back to the laptop..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Ok, must have had an issue with the EasyFlash A4160 connector that was defective. I was able to re-program the BIOS with the posted BIOS and it's still slow.

Attached are two screen shots [ATTACH type="full"]59383[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]59384[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
6.16A for BMON is strange.
Check resistance between pins 17/18 and voltage at pin 15 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Resistence between pins 17/18 on the board is measuring 3.1 ohms
Voltage at pin 15 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>) is showing only 64 mV [Note: Battery is disconnected]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U5600</CHIP> area; post its voltages.

Also test the machine with 45/60W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5600</CHIP> Voltages are as follows
 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.31v
 - <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_R_N</SIGNAL> - 8.57v
- <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_R_P</SIGNAL> - 8.57v
- <SIGNAL>BMON_IOUT</SIGNAL> - 1.8mV

I have been using a 85W Magsafe 2 charger, should I use a lower wattage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Ooops, iStat reports the same voltage for DCIN and PBus; higher than normal for an Air also.
Impossible, as you have 8.57V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Something strange, it also reports 6.16A for BMON Discrete and you have only 1.8mV (not around 3V).

Use HWMonitor and yes, connect battery and 45/60W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Put back the board after doing some minor cleaning....and MLB is working at normal speed now.

I downloaded HWMonitor and have a 60W charger to use, currently running Unigine test.....going to do an ultrasonic clean afterwards and re-test

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Slow Boot & MacOS
threads.message:
Why do you like UC so much???
If machine passes stress test, let it as is...
